STATUTORY BODIES
(Nomination of Members)


    1. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Chief Minister whether he will make a statement on Government policy in respect of the nomination of members to fill vacancies on Trusts or Boards which are within the power of Government to fill.

    The Chief Minister (Mr Lim Yew Hock): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is Government's policy to nominate persons who, by their work, profession or their record of public service, are best qualified to serve the interests of the public on the various statutory bodies.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Chief Minister confirm that two members, who were nominated to the Singapore Improvement Trust recently to fill vacancies relinquished by those retired after their term of office, are members of the Labour Front?

    The Chief Minister: Sir, I have said that the Government only nominate persons who, by their work, profession or record of public service, can best serve the public interests, and I leave it to the hon. Member to assess whether the record of these two nominees is in accordance with what we lay down.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: That does not answer the question, Sir. Does that mean that the Chief Minister confirms that the two members appointed are Labour Front members?

    Mr Speaker: There is an imputation. I cannot allow that.

PENSIONS AND COST OF LIVING ALLOWANCE
(Increase)


    2. Mr Lee Kuan Yew asked the Chief Secretary whether the question of an increase in pensions and cost of living allowance for pensioners has been decided.

We waited to get the final results of the Federation's attempts to solve this complicated problem and we are now trying to adapt them to our own circumstances.

OPIUM ADDICTS
(Legislation)


    4. Mr Goh Tong Liang asked the Attorney-General whether he will consider introducing amending legislation so that convicted opium addicts shall not be committed to prison but sent to anti-opium treatment centres.

    Mr C. H. Butterfield: Sir, I shall be introducing a Bill to make amendments to the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance at this sitting. This Bill includes an amendment to the existing law which makes a prison sentence mandatory in the case of first offenders who are considered unsuitable for treatment at an opium treatment centre. It is not, however, intended to provide that all offenders shall be sent to such centres.

TRAFFIC CONGESTION
(Relief Measures)


    7. Mr Lim Koon Teck asked the Minister for Communications and Works what steps have been taken to relieve the congestion of the traffic at-

    (i) the junction of Paya Lebar and Yio Chu Kang Roads; and

Column: 28



    (ii) the 6th milestone Yio Chu Kang Road.

    Mr Francis Thomas: I think perhaps I ought first to make clear, Mr Speaker, that there is no junction between Yio Chu Kang Road and Paya Lebar Road. They both join Upper Serangoon Road at points about 300 yards apart.

    There are a number of proposals in connection with traffic congestion. The problem in this area has been considered by the Highways Co-ordination Committee which has large-scale proposals extending from here to the Merdeka Bridge. The whole thing links up. In this particular area the works include a widening of the Yio Chu Kang Road from the junction of Upper Serangoon Road, to the Serangoon Garden Estate, and a by-pass to give direct connection to Upper Serangoon Road at its junction with Paya Lebar Road. The widening of the Yio Chu Kang Road on each side at the 6th milestone will commence when the land acquisition proceedings and removal of' squatters have been completed; and the local authorities are being requested to' carry out the by-pass scheme which should also include the roundabout at the Paya Lebar/Serangoon Roads junction. Further relief in this immediate' area will require widening the Upper Serangoon Road between the Yio Chu Kang and Paya Lebar Roads' junctions, but as this would involve demolition of' shophouses, it is not an immediate possibility.

1956-1957 SCHOOL DEVELOPMENT PLANS


    8. Mr Lim Cher Kheng asked the Minister for Education whether he will give details of the 1956-1957 development plan for English schools and Vernacular schools; and whether he has any plan for building a Malay secondary school in the Siglap-Bedok area.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, in general the primary school programme provides for the building of 18 schools a year. The present standard type schools have 15 class-rooms. The new schools will have 18 class-rooms.

Column: 29

In addition, a number of smaller schools will be built in the rural areas. Some of the new schools will be vernacular schools if the demand is sufficient and if competent teachers are available. Where the demand does not justify the use of a full school, the Government proposes, as an experiment, to introduce Chinese or Malay stream into some schools where the medium of instruction is English.

    In addition to the two secondary technical schools which have been completed this year, work has just started on two academic secondary schools of which one is to be a Malay school. This will be at Dunman Road in Katong and not in the Siglap-Bedok area. Provision is being sought in the 1957 Estimates for the building of six more secondary schools of which the present intention is that two should be Chinese schools and one a technical school.

CHINESE SCHOOLS
(Policy)


    12. Mr Lim Cher Kheng asked the Minister for Education whether he will give an assurance-.

    (a) that the management of Chinese Schools as run by the existing school committees will not be jeopardised by the adoption of the new Chinese Education Policy;

    (b) that there will not be any lowering of the standards of the textbooks and changing of curricula in the Chinese Schools; and

    (c) that the registration granted to the qualified teachers in Chinese Schools will continue to be recognised.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: To (a) the answer is there is no new Chinese Education Policy apart from the policy laid down in the White Paper. The policy applies to all schools, and aided Chinese schools will have exactly the same degree of autonomy as aided English schools.

    (b) I would refer the hon. Member to the relevant sections of the All-Party Committee Report, especially sections K, L, and M, and to paragraphs 17, 19, 20, 21 and 22 of the White Paper.

    (c) The answer is yes.

HOSPITAL AT KALLANG AIRPORT SITE


    14. Mr Lim Koon Teck asked the Minister for Health-

    (i) whether plans for the proposed Hospital at the Kallang Airport site have been completed; and

    (ii) whether Government has decided to establish a temporary cottage hospital there pending completion of the District Hospital.

    Mr A. J. Braga: Mr Speaker, Sir,

    (i) plans for the Kallang Hospital are practically completed but the finalisation of the detailed plans, which are under study by the P.W.D. architects in consultation with the Ministry of Health, is dependent upon the site. The site at the old Kallang Airport ground presents two difficulties. First, it has been ascertained that the hospital will be in the "flight funnel" for the take-off and landing of all civil aircraft. The question whether the noise created by the aircraft will be detrimental to the health of the patients has been put before the Medical Advisory Council. The next difficulty is the extra expense in piling, for it

has been found that the foundations of a multi-storeyed building will be comparatively costlier. An alternative site at Bedok is under consideration. The delay in the final decision on the site is in no way hampering the planning of the building. It is expected that it will be possible to start construction of this hospital sometime in 1957.

    (ii) Government has decided to allot the old Terminal Building to the Singapore Youth Sports Centre. A detailed study of the requirements of a cottage hospital reveals that expenditure on a temporary project cannot be justified by the resulting benefit to the public. It is considered better to press forward with the plans for a permanent district hospital. Government, however, has been given the Malayan Airways canteen which is planned to be converted into an out-patient clinic and dispensary. This will be able to cater for 600 patients a day and work on that will commence almost immediately.

    Mr Lim Koon Teck: I thank the Minister for Health for his information. Something is better than nothing and I hope the target date of 1957 will -

    Mr Braga: Oh, I appreciate the thanks!

ASSEMBLY HOUSE PRECINCTS
(Maintenance of Order and Decorum)


    The Chief Minister (Mr Lim Yew Hock): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to move,

    That this Assembly resolves that for the better maintenance of the privileges of the Legislative Assembly the Commissioner of Police be requested to make such orders and do all necessary acts and things as are required to ensure that on each day on which the Assembly is sitting during the present session due order and decorum are maintained and preserved in and around the precincts of the Assembly House.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, it is clearly desirable that the deliberations of the Assembly should be conducted in an atmosphere

Column: 37

of calm, uninfluenced by public demonstrations, and that therefore such demonstrations should not be permitted in the vicinity of the Assembly House while the Assembly is sitting.

    In the United Kingdom all meetings and assemblies of more than 50 persons have been forbidden within a distance of one mile from Westminster Hall while either House of Parliament is sitting. In addition, the House of Commons at the beginning of each session of Parliament makes a Sessional Order addressed to the Commissioner of Police requesting him to ensure freedom of access to the House and to prevent disorder. The Commissioner then issues the necessary directions regarding assemblies and processions.

    In Singapore the Deputy Commissioner of Police has powers under the Minor Offences Ordinance to make, with the Governor's previous approval, orders forbidding processions and assemblies. In October last year, Sir, on your representation, the Deputy Commissioner made an order forbidding processions and assemblies while the Assembly is sitting within an area bounded by Stamford Canal, the sea front, the left bank of the Singapore River, and North Bridge Road.

    It is felt, Sir, that it would be wise to follow United Kingdom practice in this matter and for the House to pass a resolution at the beginning of each session to request the Commissioner of Police to make such orders and take such other action as may be necessary to ensure that there shall be no disorder in the vicinity of the Assembly House on any day on which the Assembly is sitting. Sir, I beg to move.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng (Queenstown): Mr Speaker, Sir, this motion, in fact, is a revision of the previous motion that was adopted by this Assembly and it empowered you to give directives to the Commissioner of Police. In such a case, I have much pleasure in seconding the motion.

GOVERNOR'S ADDRESS

(Debate on the Address)


    The Chief Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir,I rise to move the motion standing in my name, namely,

    That this Assembly expresses its thanks to His Excellency the Governor for his Address delivered on Wednesday, 29th August, 1956.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I hope the one week's adjournment has given the Opposition

Column: 39

ample time to study the Governor's Address and this traditional motion is to give them an opportunity to debate and criticise the policy of the Government. There has been talk that some hon. Members are waiting for this day to come so that they can unleash the fury of their attack. This is indeed, Sir, a very healthy sign, for our parliamentary form of government demands a virile and constructive Opposition.

    This is the first business sitting of the Assembly since I took office as Chief Minister last June, and I am therefore taking this first opportunity of making a lengthy statement on why I accepted office and what are the Government's plans for Merdeka.

    I accepted office, Sir, because I believed that I had the confidence of the public, and I have received no indication that this confidence has waned. I believed that there was a job to be done in the interests of the people and that it was my duty, as a Malayan, not to shirk it. I sincerely believed that it was the desire of the people's representatives in this Assembly to have another crack at the Colonial Office. I sincerely believed, and still sincerely believe, Sir, that when I lead the next delegation to London to resume the constitutional talks, I would have the full support and co-operation of all Parties in this Assembly. These were my beliefs which led me to accept office as Chief Minister, an office to which, in God's truth, I did not aspire. These beliefs have given me sustenance in the carrying out of a job, in fact, two jobs which are onerous and, at the present time, full of difficulties. If my beliefs are unfounded, then I shall have no strength and no confidence left in me to continue working for the task that is immediately ahead of us - the attainment of complete internal self-government - and I am therefore, Sir, asking this House to confirm or shatter those parts of my beliefs as have a direct bearing on them. This motion, Sir, is therefore to be treated as a vote of confidence.

Column: 40



    Sir, I formed my Government with the same colleagues who held office in the previous Government, without any change in their portfolio, although this meant that I have to tackle two jobs - that of Chief Minister and of Minister for Labour and Welfare. I did this, Sir, in order to have the advantage of continuity of personnel to ensure continuity of policy. I did not seek further coalition to strengthen the Government and sustain us in office. The Labour Front Coalition Government do not propose to hold office up to 1959, the natural life of this Assembly under the present constitution. The Government propose to reopen talks with the Colonial Office by April next year for complete internal self-government. If the talks are successful, a new constitution will come into being; and if we fail, the purpose of my accepting office will have come to an end.

    I have been silent, and deliberately so, on our plans for Merdeka because I feel a new strategy is called for as a result of experience gained over the failure of the last talks. This time we must plan, and plan well, so that we can negotiate from a position of strength. In this planning there will, of course, be consultations with Members of the Opposition with a view to united effort and united action. Let us not play party politics in this great task. Let us, however, show that, as true Malayans, we are united in the fight for Merdeka, because in unity we beget strength and in unity we brook no failure. This is another big reason, Sir, which impels me to ask this House to treat my motion as a vote of confidence.

    When I visited London last July to attend the Labour Administration Conference in Oxford, I took the opportunity offered me to have informal discussions with the Secretary of State, and I am strongly convinced that if the Government have the fullest support and co-operation of the Opposition, there can be no failure when the next delegation goes to London.

Column: 41



    I have set, Sir, April 1957 as the latest date for the reopening of the talks with the Colonial Office, but this date can be advanced by two or three months if our plans are ready by then.

    Sir, I am most conscious of the fact that the Government and the Opposition are equally represented in this House. We are back again to the 16-a-side. During the previous session of this House one hon. Member was wont to point out at various times that the Government Benches had only 12 elected Members against 13 in the Opposition. I was quite aware of the reasons which prompted him to launch this criticism. Today this side of the House has only 11 elected Members, whereas the opposition ranks have increased by one. Be that as it may, Sir, I am not in the least dismayed.

    We are at present working under the Rendel Constitution, a constitution which we have all expressed a desire to throw out, and I have already described how best we can achieve this.     On 16th July, 1956, the Commissioner of Police launched a vigorous campaign known as "Operation Dagger" designed to disorganise the societies and to disperse the members.
